comments:
Found in build M200601170000.

Repro:
1. Open the New Project wizard (File > New > Project...).
2. Choose J2EE > Enterprise Application Project and click Next.
3. Enter a project name and click Next.
4. On the Select Project Facets page, click Next.
5. On the J2EE Modules to Add to the EAR page, click New Module...
6. Deselect the "Create default modules" checkbox, choose Enterprise Java Bean, and click Next.
7. Enter a project name and click Finish.
8. Agree to the license agreement, decline to switch perspectives.
9. On the J2EE Modules to Add to the EAR page, click New Module...
10. Deselect the "Create default modules" checkbox, choose Web, and click Next.
11. Enter a project name and click Finish.
12. On the J2EE Modules to Add to the EAR page, select the just-created EJB and web modules and click Finish.
13. In the project properties for the web project, go to the J2EE Module Dependencies page and check the box to add the EJB module/JAR as a dependency.  
14. Click OK.

Expected: No error, no message.  

Result: Error message appears: "An error has occurred. See error log for more details."  The error log yields the stack trace below.

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.application.internal.operations.ClassPathSelection.getSelectedClasspathElements(ClassPathSelection.java:222)

at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog$2.widgetSelected(Dialog.java:556)

I forgot to add one of the important bits: if you open up the J2EE Module Dependencies page for the web project again, you'll see that the dependency on the EJB was NOT added.

This bug still repros in M200601251151 and I200601270511.  My apologies if the fix is in a later build; I'm not sure how to determine which build a fix ought to be in based on the date of the "fix is in" comment.

Verified fix in build I200601291054; tested repro and checked that the dependency is added.  Another dev alerted me to the existence of the new "what is fixed" reports, which answers my question of how to determine whether a build contains the fix for a given bug.
